awd_titl_txt: NRI: Decentralized Feedback Control Design for Cooperative Robotic Walking with Application to Powered Prosthetic Legs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the creation of innovative decentralized controllers for legged locomotion. Decentralized controllers require only local information to accomplish their function. In the case of legged locomotion, decentralization is desirable for several reasons. For prosthetics, where the purpose is to replace a lost natural limb, it is impractical to wire the user with a profusion of sensors. Therefore the prosthetic device must primarily rely on its own built-in measurements. Another advantage of decentralization is the management of complexity. As robots become more sophisticated, the number of variables that must be monitored for a complete description of the system status becomes so large that top-down controllers are costly or infeasible to implement. The challenge of decentralized control is made substantially more difficult because walking and running are hybrid dynamic behaviors, that is, the dynamics follow a completely different set of rules when, for example, a foot is planted on the ground, compared to when it is swinging in the air. This project will address the substantial analytical difficulties caused by these features. This project will advance the state of the art in advanced lower limb prosthetics, as well as in locomotion for the next generation of legged robots. 

This project will investigate the systematic design of decentralized feedback controllers that coordinate low-dimensional subsystems to achieve robust legged locomotion, overcoming the curse of dimensionality in legged robots and enabling cooperative human-machine walking with powered prosthetic legs. The project draws upon robotics, optimization, and feedback control theory to advance two key innovations: (1) creating algorithms to systematically design robust stabilizing decentralized controllers for cooperative subsystems; and (2) transferring the decentralized control framework into practice with an experimental quadruped and a powered prosthetic leg. The problem of creating decentralized nonlinear controllers for robust dynamic walking with interconnected subsystems, coordinated only by a common gait cycle phasing variable, will be formulated in the context linear and bilinear matrix inequalities. The theoretical significance of these algorithms include: (1) they are powerful tools for the design of general nonlinear decentralized feedback control schemes; (2) they explicitly account for underactuation to account for walking motions that are not flat-footed; (3) they provide cooperation between subsystems of complex walking models with high dimensionality and strong interactions; and (4) they provably stabilize full-dimensional hybrid dynamical models of walking robots rather than simplified models. This decentralized control framework is technologically significant because it can be readily transferred into practical high-DOF legged robots, as well as wearable robots for physical rehabilitation.

por.por_cntn:
While rapidly advancing technologies enable the design of increasingly sophisticated legged robots, the feedback control algorithms currently used to achieve stable dynamic locomotion are tailored to centralized algorithms that cannot scale with the increasing dimensionality of these robots. In addition, the centralized nature of these control approaches prevents their transfer into local controllers for wearable robots like prosthetic legs. This project addressed the design of decentralized feedback controllers that coordinate low-dimensional subsystems to achieve stable dynamic locomotion, overcoming the curse of dimensionality in legged robots and enabling cooperative human-machine walking with powered prosthetic legs. This was a collaborative project between Virginia Tech (VT) and the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD).


In terms of Intellectual Merit, multiple novel decentralized control design methods were developed under this work and each has been investigated on different legged machines. The first approach assumed a family of parameterized and decentralized nonlinear controllers to coordinate interconnected subsystems based on a common phasing variable. The robust stabilization problem of dynamic walking gaits is then translated into an iterative sequence of optimization problems involving matrix inequalities. The power of the algorithm was demonstrated through designing a set of robust decentralized controllers for walking of an autonomous bipedal robot and a decentralization scheme motivated by amputee locomotion with a transpelvic prosthetic leg. By conforming to the natural symmetries present in quadrupedal locomotion, the second approach presented a decomposition method to synthesize decentralized control algorithms based on real-time optimization. The effectiveness of this decentralized control scheme was demonstrated for the stabilization of forward walking and in-place stepping gaits for three different decentralization schemes for quadrupeds: left-right, front-hind, and diagonal decompositions. The third approach provided a formal foundation to extend the decomposition approach for asymmetric models of locomotion such as amputee locomotion with powered prosthetic legs. This latter approach can significantly reduce the number of controller parameters to be optimized for the synthesis of decentralized controllers compared to the first approach. The approach was investigated for multi-domain models of amputee locomotion with a powered knee-ankle prosthetic leg. Finally, the project developed the synthesis of distributed control algorithms for cooperative locomotion of robotic guide dogs and humans.  


In addition to the systematic design methods of decentralized controllers for legged robots, the work also developed a formal foundation to design asymptotic estimators (observers) and dynamic output feedback controllers for the stabilization of dynamic gaits when there is a limited number of state measurements from legged machines. Moreover, the work investigated a special class of nonlinear controllers for bipedal robots, referred to as nonholonomic hybrid zero dynamics (HZD). The work formally studied the stability and robustness of dynamic gaits under nonholonomic HZD and showed that nonholonomic HZD controllers can robustly stabilize a broader range of walking gaits that are not stabilizable through traditional HZD controllers. The work also developed a control approach that unifies the gait cycle of a powered knee–ankle prosthesis using a continuous, user-synchronized sense of phase. The UTD team designed a powered knee–ankle prosthetic leg, which implements high-torque actuators with low-reduction transmissions for the purpose of validation. 


In terms of Broader Impacts, this project's innovations in decentralized feedback control of highly dynamic legged locomotion contribute to the development of sophisticated and high degree-of-freedom legged robots. These machines can either assist humans, or stand in for them, in situations of extreme danger, such as when responding to an industrial accident, a nuclear incident, or a fire in a home. Estimates indicate that by 2050 the U.S. will incur a two-fold increase in the incidence of amputation and stroke, due largely to the prevalence of vascular diseases. This also underlines the importance of the developed decentralized control algorithms to guarantee the stability of local controllers during cooperative human-machine walking. In terms of education, multiple PhD students at the VT and UTD sites were supported via this project to work on their dissertations and publications. In addition, a graduate course on feedback control of dynamic legged locomotion was developed at the VT site. Both sites hosted several lab tours for K-12 students, and maintained research websites and YouTube channels to disseminate this project's results to a broad audience.
